channel.title: Comments on: Are you a real programmer, do you know all these artifacts you should know according to Uncle Bob?
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Meta-Knight
item.dc:creator: Meta-Knight
item.content:encoded:
I read this book and loved it, but I don’t remember this part about charts and diagrams that you should know. And I’m still sleeping well even though I know about only 4 of them!

Uncle Bob is overly strict about some things (no more than 3 function parameters, 20-line functions, etc.). I think his books are very instructive and valuable, and I’d recommend them strongly, but you have to be pragmatic about his advice.

You can still be a professional without knowing Nassi-Schneiderman Charts, and you can still produce clean code even if you have some 4-parameter functions ðŸ˜‰

item.title: By: chopstik
item.dc:creator: chopstik
item.description: Four - but can't say as though I've used all of them. I must really suck...
item.content:encoded: Four – but can’t say as though I’ve used all of them. I must really suck…

item.title: By: Howie Feltersnatch
item.dc:creator: Howie Feltersnatch
item.content:encoded:
Only heard of 6….working experience with 4.

Not convinced at least two of those are not rare diseases.

item.title: By: Alex Ullrich
item.dc:creator: Alex Ullrich
item.content:encoded:
Yeah I’m with Chrissie – while I might use that kind of thing once in a while to help think something through, I can’t recall the last time I did anything beyond a back-of-napkin type sketch. I wonder if I might know what the others are if I googled them.

My feeling has always been that if you actually have one of these artifacts (at least the ones I recognize) in front of you, it is probably already out of date. I also haven’t worked for the NASAs or Lockheed Martins of the world – I imagine in such environments this kind of thing is terrifically important but for the majority of actual work I’ve done they would be massive time wasters.

item.title: By: Matt Velic
item.dc:creator: Matt Velic
item.description: Wow. Maybe a third. I run into arguments like that often - if you don't know x, y, and z, you need to learn them to be good at random activity. It's bull. We try, we study, we fail, we learn: that's how we get good.
item.content:encoded: Wow. Maybe a third. I run into arguments like that often – if you don’t know x, y, and z, you need to learn them to be good at random activity. It’s bull. We try, we study, we fail, we learn: that’s how we get good.

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.description: Four (4) for me - maybe more if I read his definitions. Sounds like you should be reading something else.
item.content:encoded: Four (4) for me – maybe more if I read his definitions. Sounds like you should be reading something else.

item.title: By: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.description: I know six and I know how much those suck so I don't want to know the rest.
item.content:encoded: I know six and I know how much those suck so I don’t want to know the rest.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: I did a search for Parnas Tables and all I get back is some images of restaurant tables.....my Google-fu juice must have run out as well ;-)
item.content:encoded: I did a search for Parnas Tables and all I get back is some images of restaurant tables…..my Google-fu juice must have run out as well ðŸ˜‰

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.description: Only a few for me too (5 or 6, guess I'd have to make sure my definition and his matched for some of the more generic terms). There are lots of things I would consider more important than what he has on that list.
item.content:encoded: Only a few for me too (5 or 6, guess I’d have to make sure my definition and his matched for some of the more generic terms). There are lots of things I would consider more important than what he has on that list.
